parameters.query:
SELECT *
FROM conversation_history
WHERE
  session_id = $1
  AND id > $2;

INSERT INTO rag_store (project_id, session_id, original_content, role, embedding)
VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4, '{{ JSON.stringify($json.embedding) }}');

INSERT INTO memory_commit_log (session_id, last_processed_message_id, processed_at)
VALUES ($1, $2, NOW())
ON CONFLICT (session_id)
DO UPDATE SET
    last_processed_message_id = EXCLUDED.last_processed_message_id,
    processed_at = NOW();

options.queryReplacement: ={{ $('Trigger: Receive Session ID').first().json.body.chat_session_id }},{{ $('Calculate New High-Water Mark').first().json.new_high_water_mark }}

parameters.query: SELECT xata_id AS project_id FROM project_contexts WHERE chat_session_id = $1

parameters.content:
## System Documentation: Context Distillation & Indexing


Workflow Name: System: Context Distillation & Indexing for Documentation
Source File: System__Context_Distillation___Indexing_for_Documentation.json
Project Lead: Mike Holland
System Architect: Gemini Pro
1. Overall Goal
This workflow serves as the dedicated "Commit to Memory" function for the Chat 8 UI. Its purpose is to solve the problem of limited context windows in LLMs by creating a persistent, long-term memory store. It is triggered manually by the user, reads the recent, unprocessed conversation history for a given session, uses a powerful AI model to distill that conversation into a set of atomic facts, generates vector embeddings for those facts, and saves them to the rag_store database.
2. Key Components & Architecture
Trigger: A unique n8n Webhook (...6c1ce608...) listens for POST requests from the Chat 8 UI's "Commit to Memory" button.
Database: It interacts with three key tables in the Postgres database: conversation_history (to read new messages), memory_commit_log (to track progress with a high-water mark), and rag_store (to save the final indexed memories).
External Services: It makes two distinct calls to the OpenAI API: one to the Chat Completions endpoint for fact distillation and another to the Embeddings endpoint for vectorization.
Logic: The workflow is a sequential data processing pipeline that includes a crucial "high-water mark" system to prevent duplicate processing of messages.
3. Step-by-Step Data Flow
The workflow executes in a clear, linear sequence:
Trigger: Receive Session ID: The workflow is triggered by a POST request from the UI. The payload contains the chat_session_id and rag_session_id for the current conversation.
Get Project ID: A Postgres node takes the chat_session_id and queries the project_contexts table to find the associated permanent project_id.
DB: Get High-Water Mark: A Postgres node queries the memory_commit_log table to find the ID of the last message that was processed for this chat_session_id. It uses a COALESCE function to safely default to 0 if no record exists (i.e., this is the first commit for the session).
Set: Watermark Value: A Set node takes the high_water_mark from the previous step and prepares it for the next query.
DB: Get Conversation History: A Postgres node queries the conversation_history table, fetching all messages for the current chat_session_id whose id is greater than the highWaterMark.
Calculate New High-Water Mark: A Code node iterates through the messages retrieved in the previous step and finds the highest message id. This value will be saved at the end of the workflow.
IF: New Messages Found?: An If node checks if any new messages were returned. If the count is zero, the workflow stops cleanly. If new messages exist, it proceeds.
Format: Assemble Transcript: A Code node takes the new messages and formats them into a clean, human-readable transcript string.
Build: OpenAI Request Body: A Code node constructs the full JSON payload for the fact-distillation call to the OpenAI API, including a detailed system prompt and the conversation transcript.
Execute: OpenAI API Call: An HTTPRequest node sends the payload to the OpenAI Chat Completions API (gpt-4o).
Set: Extracted Summary: A Set node parses the AI's response and extracts the JSON string containing the distilled facts.
Chunk: Distilled Summary: A Code node parses the JSON string of facts and splits them, outputting each individual fact as a separate item to be processed in the following steps.
API: Create Embeddings (HTTP) node: (Runs for each fact) An HTTPRequest node takes each fact and calls the OpenAI Embeddings API (text-embedding-3-small) to generate its vector embedding.
Merge Embedding with Original Data: A Code node (not a Merge node) runs to assemble the final, complete payload for the database, combining the project_id, session_id, the fact text, the role (summary), and the new embedding vector.
DB: Insert Embedding1: (Runs for each fact) A Postgres node executes the INSERT query to save the complete record for each fact into the rag_store table. It correctly links each memory to the project_id and rag_session_id that were generated in Step 2.
DB: Update High-Water Mark: The final database operation. A Postgres node performs an UPSERT on the memory_commit_log table, saving the new_high_water_mark calculated in Step 6. This ensures the next run will only process messages created after this point.
Count Facts & Respond to Webhook6: A final Code node counts the number of facts committed, and the Respond to Webhook node sends a detailed success message (including a "toast" for the UI) back to the user, completing the cycle.

parameters.query:
SELECT
      project_name,
      chat_session_id,
      rag_session_id,
      xata_id,
      description,
      persona
  FROM
      project_contexts
  ORDER BY
      xata_createdat DESC;

parameters.content:
## System Documentation: Setup Workflow - Project Launcher


Workflow Name: Setup Workflow: Project Launcher for Documentation
Source File: Setup_Workflow__Project_Launcher_for_Documentation.json
Project Lead: Mike Holland
System Architect: Gemini Pro
1. Overall Goal
This workflow serves as the primary "receptionist" and setup engine for the Chat 8 UI. It is a dual-function workflow that automates both the creation of new, simple projects and the retrieval of the complete list of existing projects. Its core purpose is to manage the project_contexts table, ensuring each project has a unique set of identifiers before handing control back to the UI.
2. Key Components & Architecture
Trigger: A unique n8n Webhook (...a61a290c...) listens for POST requests from the Chat 8 UI's initial launcher screen.
Database: It interacts exclusively with the project_contexts table in the Postgres database to create new project records and retrieve the full project list.
Logic: The workflow uses an If node to act as a switch, directing the incoming request down one of two distinct paths based on an action property in the request body.
3. Step-by-Step Data Flow
The workflow begins with a single entry point and immediately branches based on the user's intent.
Webhook3: The workflow is triggered by a POST request from the UI. The payload contains a JSON body with an action key, which will be either create_project or list_projects.
Branch A: "List Existing Projects"
This is the True path of the If1 node.
Get Project List: A Postgres node executes a SELECT query to retrieve the project_name, chat_session_id, rag_session_id, and xata_id for all records in the project_contexts table.
If1: The workflow logic for this branch is slightly counter-intuitive. The If node checks if the result of the Get Project List query has more than 0 items. If True, it proceeds down this "List Projects" path.
Code3: A Code node takes the list of projects from the database and transforms it to match the data contract expected by the UI, ensuring all necessary keys (project_name, session_id, project_id, rag_session_id) are present.
Respond to Webhook4: The final Respond to Webhook node sends the formatted list of projects back to the UI, which then uses it to populate the project selection dropdown.
Branch B: "Create New Project"
This is the False path of the If1 node.
Code2: A Code node receives the projectName from the webhook. It generates a new, unique chat_session_id and rag_session_id based on the project name and the current timestamp.
Postgres1: This Postgres node executes an INSERT query, using the data from the Code2 node to create a new record in the project_contexts table. It uses RETURNING xata_id to get the permanent project ID back from the database.
Respond to Webhook5: The final Respond to Webhook node sends a success response back to the UI, providing it with the newly created chat_session_id and rag_session_id so it can initialize the new chat session.

parameters.query: SELECT project_name FROM project_contexts WHERE project_name = $1;
UPDATE project_contexts SET chat_session_id = $1 WHERE xata_id = $2;

parameters.content:
## System Documentation: Create Project Workflow


Workflow Name: Create Project Workflow (as inferred from context)
Source File: Main_Chat_Workflow_for_Documentation (1).json
Project Lead: Mike Holland
System Architect: Gemini Pro
1. Overall Goal
This workflow serves as the dedicated backend process for creating a new, simple project. Its sole purpose is to receive a project name from the UI, ensure it doesn't already exist, create all the necessary records and IDs in the database, and return a success response to the UI so a new chat session can begin. It acts as a secure and robust entry point for Scenario 1.
2. Key Components & Architecture
Trigger: A unique n8n Webhook (...d0b91f11...) listens for POST requests from the Chat 8 UI.
Database: It interacts exclusively with the project_contexts table in the Postgres database to check for duplicates and create new project records.
Logic: The workflow follows a simple conditional path: if the project already exists, it fails gracefully; if not, it proceeds with creation.
3. Step-by-Step Data Flow
The workflow executes in a clear, linear sequence:
Webhook: The workflow is triggered when the user submits a new project name from the UI. The payload contains { "projectName": "..." }.
Check if Project Exists: A Postgres node immediately queries the project_contexts table to see if any record already has the provided projectName.
If (Project Exists?): An If node checks the result of the previous query.
If True (project exists): The workflow takes the True branch and immediately triggers the Respond to Webhook1 node, which sends a specific error message back to the UI, stopping the process.
If False (project is new): The workflow proceeds down the main False branch to create the project.
Code (Prepare SQL Parameters): A Code node runs to prepare the data for the database INSERT command. It generates a unique rag_session_id and sessionId and assembles all the required values into an array (sql_params).
Postgres (Create Project Record): This Postgres node executes the main INSERT query, using the sql_params from the previous step to create the new record in the project_contexts table. Crucially, it uses RETURNING * to output the full, newly created database row, including the permanent xata_id.
Generate Thread ID: A Code node generates a new, unique chat_session_id (formatted as session_...).
Save Thread ID to Project: A Postgres node executes an UPDATE query. It takes the new_thread_id and the xata_id from the previous steps and updates the project record to include the new chat session ID.
Prepare Success Response: A Set node takes the project_id (from the xata_id) and the session_id (from the new_thread_id) and formats them into a clean JSON object.
Respond to Webhook: The final Respond to Webhook node sends this success object back to the UI, providing it with all the necessary IDs to initialize the new chat session.

parameters.query: INSERT INTO rag_store (project_id, session_id, original_content, role, embedding) VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4, $5);

WITH generated_ids AS (
    SELECT
        (EXTRACT(EPOCH FROM NOW())::BIGINT)::text AS project_id,
        'chat_' || (EXTRACT(EPOCH FROM NOW())::BIGINT) AS chat_session_id,
        'rag_' || REPLACE('{{$json.body.projectName}}', ' ', '_') || '_' || (EXTRACT(EPOCH FROM NOW())::BIGINT) AS rag_session_id
),
inserted_project AS (
    INSERT INTO project_contexts (
        project_name,
        session_id,
        chat_session_id,
        rag_session_id,
        status,
        description,
        notes,
        lead_contact
    )
    SELECT
        '{{$json.body.projectName}}',
        g.chat_session_id,
        g.chat_session_id,
        g.rag_session_id,
        'Active',
        'Project created from Indexed URL',
        'Source URL: {{$json.body.jsonUrl}}',
        'Project created from URL'
    FROM generated_ids g
)
SELECT project_id, chat_session_id, rag_session_id FROM generated_ids;

parameters.content:
## System Documentation: RAG Indexing Workflow


**IMPLEMENTATION NOTES - TIMEOUT FIX APPLIED**
This workflow has been updated with timeout configurations to resolve HTTP request failures in VM Docker environments.
- Create Embedding1 node: 120 second timeout added
- HTTP Request GCS Fetch1 node: 60 second timeout added
- Workflow execution timeout: 1 hour limit
- Error handling: saveManualExecutions enabled for debugging

RECOMMENDED RETRY LOGIC (for future enhancement):
- Add Code node after each HTTP Request for exponential backoff retry
- Implement 3 retry attempts with 5-second delays
- Log timeout errors for monitoring and alerting


Workflow Name: RAG Indexing Workflow for Documentation
Source File: RAG_Indexing_Workflow_for_Documentation.json
Project Lead: Mike Holland
System Architect: Gemini Pro
1. Overall Goal
This workflow serves as the dedicated data pipeline for bootstrapping a new project with an existing knowledge base. Its purpose is to receive a URL to a JSON file and a new project name from the UI, create the necessary project records in the database, and then systematically process the contents of the JSON file. It chunks the text, generates vector embeddings for each chunk, and saves them to the long-term memory store (rag_store), permanently associating them with the newly created project.
2. Key Components & Architecture
Trigger: A unique n8n Webhook (...303639ed...) listens for POST requests from the Chat 8 UI's "Create from URL" feature.
Database: It interacts with both the project_contexts table (to create the new project) and the rag_store table (to save the indexed memories).
External Services: It makes calls to Google Cloud Storage (GCS) to fetch the source JSON and to the OpenAI API to generate embeddings.
Logic: The workflow is a sequential pipeline: create the project, fetch the data, chunk it, create embeddings, and save everything to the database.
3. Step-by-Step Data Flow
The workflow executes in a clear, linear sequence:
Webhook2: The workflow is triggered when the user submits a JSON URL and a new project name from the UI. The payload contains { "projectName": "...", "jsonUrl": "..." }.
Create Project Entry1: A Postgres node immediately executes a complex SQL query. This single query is responsible for:
Generating a new, unique project_id (numeric), chat_session_id, and rag_session_id.
Inserting a new record into the project_contexts table with these new IDs and the provided project name.
Returning the newly generated IDs for use in subsequent steps.
HTTP Request GCS Fetch1: An HTTPRequest node takes the jsonUrl from the initial webhook and fetches the raw text content of the JSON file from Google Cloud Storage. **TIMEOUT: 60 seconds**
Chunk Code1: A sophisticated Code node takes the raw text from the file. It intelligently splits the text into smaller, manageable chunks suitable for embedding, ensuring no chunk exceeds a maximum character limit. It outputs a list of items, each containing a text chunk.
Filter1: A simple Filter node ensures that no empty chunks proceed, preventing wasted API calls.
Create Embedding1: (Runs for each chunk) An HTTPRequest node takes each text chunk and sends it to the OpenAI embeddings API (text-embedding-ada-002) to generate a vector embedding. **TIMEOUT: 120 seconds**
Merge Embedding with Chunk Data1: A Merge node combines the original chunk data with the newly generated embedding vector from the previous step.
Prepare for DB1: A Set node takes the merged data and restructures it, creating clean fields (session_id_for_insert, original_content_for_db, etc.) ready for the next step.
Format Vector for Postgres1: A Code node takes the embedding vector (which is a JavaScript array) and converts it into the specific string format (e.g., "[0.1, 0.2, ...]") required by the pgvector database type.
Insert Embedding to Xata1: (Runs for each chunk) This is the final, critical database operation. A Postgres node takes the fully prepared data for each chunk and executes an INSERT query to save it to the rag_store table. It correctly links each memory to the project_id and rag_session_id that were generated in Step 2.
Prepare Final Response1: After all chunks have been successfully inserted, a Set node runs once to format a clean success message.
Respond to Webhook3: The final Respond to Webhook node sends the success object (containing the new project_id, session_id, and rag_session_id) back to the UI, signaling that the project has been created and indexed, and a new chat session can begin.

## System Documentation: Main Chat Workflow


Workflow Name: Main Chat Workflow for Documentation
Version: As of file provided
Project Lead: Mike Holland
System Architect: Gemini Pro
1. Overall Goal
This n8n workflow serves as the central orchestration layer for the Chat 8 user interface. Its primary purpose is to receive user input, intelligently enrich it with multiple forms of contextlong-term memory from a RAG store and short-term conversational historyand generate a context-aware response from a large language model. It also includes a new feature for automatically committing "remember" intents to memory.
2. Key Components & Architecture
The system is comprised of several key components that work in concert:
Frontend: The Chat 8 UI (Chat_8_V7.html) captures user input and displays the final response.
Backend Orchestration: This n8n workflow manages the entire data flow and logic.
Long-Term Memory: A Postgres database containing the rag_store for vectorized knowledge.
Short-Term Memory: The same Postgres database, using the conversation_history table for recent conversational turns.
The workflow's core architecture is a multi-branch parallel processing system. After initial input, it splits into distinct paths to gather different types of context, which are then merged before the final AI call.
3. Step-by-Step Data Flow
The workflow executes in several distinct phases:
Phase 1: Ingestion and Preparation
Webhook1: The workflow is triggered by a POST request from the UI. It is configured to handle pre-flight OPTIONS requests for CORS compatibility.
Get Session ID & Input: A Code node parses the incoming request body. It validates that chat_session_id and chatInput are present and transforms all key IDs to a consistent camelCase format (session_Id, rag_session_Id, project_Id) for use within the workflow.
Save User Message to History: A Postgres node immediately saves the user's message to the conversation_history table, ensuring a complete and persistent log of the interaction.
Preserve Current Inputs: A critical Set node creates a stable, preserved copy of the key inputs (session_Id, chatInput, rag_session_Id, etc.). This node acts as a central hub, providing a reliable data source for all subsequent parallel branches.
Phase 2: Auto-Commit Branch (Side Process)
Running in parallel to the main chat logic.
Config: Auto-Commit Enabled: A Set node acts as a feature flag, enabling the auto-commit functionality.
If Remember Intent: An If node checks if the user's chatInput starts with the word "remember".
Auto Commit via Webhook: If the intent is to remember, an HTTPRequest node triggers the separate "Commit to Memory" workflow, passing the necessary IDs to save the new fact in the background.
Phase 3: Main Logic Branching
If Rag is Active: This is the primary traffic controller. It checks if a rag_session_Id was provided.
If True: The workflow proceeds down the full RAG path to retrieve long-term memory.
If False: The workflow bypasses the RAG steps and proceeds directly to retrieve only the short-term conversational history.
Phase 4: The RAG Path (Dual-Retrieval)
This path executes if RAG is active.
Create Query Embedding: An HTTPRequest node takes the user's chatInput and calls the OpenAI API to convert it into a vector embedding.
Format Data for Vector Search: A Code node prepares the data for the database search, formatting the embedding vector into the required string format for pgvector.
Parallel Retrieval: The workflow splits again to perform two simultaneous database lookups:
Retrieve Committed Memory: A Postgres node searches the rag_store for memories from the live conversation.
Retrieve RAG Chunks: A Postgres node searches the rag_store for memories from the initial bootstrapped knowledge base.
Merge1: A Merge node combines the results from both retrieval steps into a single list.
RAG Context consolidator: A Code node takes the merged list, removes any duplicate memories, and formats the unique results into a single, clean block of text.
Format History for AI: A Code node takes the consolidated text and wraps it in a standard { role: 'system', content: '...' } object, ready for the final prompt.
Phase 5: Final Prompt Assembly & AI Call
Get Recent history: (Runs in parallel to the RAG path) A Postgres node queries the conversation_history table for the last 6 turns of the conversation.
Format Recent History: A Code node formats these turns into the standard OpenAI message format.
Format Current Input: A Code node formats the user's current message into the standard format.
Merge: This is the final assembly point. A Merge node combines the three streams of context:
Input 1: The RAG context (from Format History for AI).
Input 2: The recent conversational history (from Format Recent History).
Input 3: The user's current message (from Format Current Input).
Build OpenAI Payload1: A sophisticated Code node takes the fully merged data. It intelligently selects the correct system prompt (persona), assembles the final message array in the correct order (system prompt, RAG context, history, user message), and builds the complete JSON payload for the AI.
HTTP Request1: Sends the final payload to the OpenAI Chat Completions API.
Phase 6: Response and Finalization
Code1: A Code node parses the response from OpenAI, extracts the AI's reply, and performs cleaning and truncation. It also checks for any status messages from the background Auto-Commit process and appends them to the reply.
Postgres2 (Save AI Reply): Saves the AI's generated response back to the conversation_history table.
Respond to Webhook2: Sends the final, clean reply back to the Chat 8 UI, completing the cycle.

parameters.query:
SELECT role, content
  FROM conversation_history
  WHERE session_id = $1
  ORDER BY created_at DESC
  LIMIT 6

parameters.jsonBody: ={{ { chat_session_id: $('Preserve Current Inputs').first().json.session_Id, rag_session_id: $('Preserve Current Inputs').first().json.rag_session_Id } }}

parameters.query:
SELECT
  original_content,
  role,
  embedding <=> $3::vector AS distance
FROM
  rag_store
WHERE
  project_id = $1 AND session_id = $2
ORDER BY
  distance ASC
LIMIT 3

SELECT
  original_content,
  role,
  embedding <=> $3::vector AS distance
FROM
  rag_store
WHERE
  project_id = $1 AND session_id = $2
ORDER BY
  distance ASC
LIMIT 3

SELECT role, content, created_at
FROM conversation_history
WHERE session_id = $1
ORDER BY created_at ASC
LIMIT $2;

parameters.content:
## Load Conversation History

# System Documentation: Load Conversation History Workflow

**Workflow Name:** Load Conversation History
**Version:** v1.1.0
**Created:** October 23, 2025
**Project Lead:** Mike Holland
**System Architect:** Claude Code AI Assistant

---

## 1. Overall Goal

This n8n workflow provides a dedicated API endpoint for loading complete conversation history from the database. Its primary purpose is to enable **platform-agnostic chat persistence** by allowing the frontend to retrieve full conversation context from any device, regardless of localStorage availability.

Unlike the Master Chat Workflow's "Get Recent history" node (which loads only the last 6 messages for immediate context), this workflow is designed to load entire conversations for UI display and cross-device synchronization.

---

## 2. Key Features

### Platform-Agnostic Architecture
- **Database as Source of Truth**: Conversations persist in PostgreSQL, not browser localStorage
- **Cross-Device Access**: Same conversation accessible from any computer/browser
- **Configurable Context Window**: Frontend controls how many messages to load (20-100+)
- **Graceful Fallback**: Frontend can fall back to localStorage if endpoint unavailable

### Robust Response Handling
- **Normalization Layer**: Always returns consistent array structure
- **Empty Session Support**: Returns `[]` instead of undefined/null for new sessions
- **CORS Enabled**: Works with GitHub Pages and other cross-domain deployments
- **Error Prevention**: Code node prevents JSON parsing errors in frontend

---

## 3. Architecture Overview

This is a **4-node linear workflow**:

```
Webhook Trigger  Postgres Query  Code Normalization  Response
```

Each node has a specific, focused responsibility:

1. **Webhook**: Receive POST request with session_id
2. **Postgres**: Query conversation_history table
3. **Code**: Normalize results to consistent array format
4. **Response**: Return JSON with CORS headers

---

## 4. Step-by-Step Data Flow

### Phase 1: Webhook Trigger
**Node:** "Webhook: Load History Trigger"
**Type:** Webhook (POST)
**Path:** `/webhook/load-conversation-history`

**Input from Frontend:**
```json
{
  "chat_session_id": "session_vqf27hq8x",
  "max_context": 100
}
```

**Key Points:**
- Accepts POST requests only
- `chat_session_id` (required): The session to load
- `max_context` (optional): Number of messages to retrieve (default: 100)
- Frontend sends `chat_session_id` per Master Data Contract

---

### Phase 2: Database Query
**Node:** "Postgres: Get Conversation History"
**Type:** Postgres (Execute Query)
**Credential:** "Postgres account" (shared with Master Workflow)

**SQL Query:**
```sql
SELECT role, content, created_at
FROM conversation_history
WHERE session_id = $1
ORDER BY created_at ASC
LIMIT $2;
```

**Query Parameters:**
```javascript
={{ [$json.body.chat_session_id, $json.body.max_context || 100] }}
```

**Field Mapping:**
- Frontend sends: `chat_session_id`
- Database uses: `session_id`
- Parameter mapping handles the translation

**Data Retrieved:**
- `role`: "user" or "assistant"
- `content`: The actual message text
- `created_at`: Timestamp for chronological ordering

**Sort Order:** `ASC` (oldest first) - Frontend can reverse if needed for display

**Important:** `alwaysOutputData: true` ensures node executes even with 0 results

---

### Phase 3: Response Normalization
**Node:** "Code: Normalize Response"
**Type:** Code (JavaScript)
**Purpose:** Prevent undefined/null responses that break frontend JSON parsing

**JavaScript Logic:**
```javascript
// Normalize Postgres results to always return an array
const items = $input.all();

// Extract messages from Postgres results
const messages = items.map(item => ({
  role: item.json.role,
  content: item.json.content,
  created_at: item.json.created_at
}));

// Get session_id from webhook
const sessionId = $('Webhook: Load History Trigger').first().json.body.chat_session_id;

// Return normalized response
return [
  {
    json: {
      success: true,
      messages: messages,
      count: messages.length,
      session_id: sessionId
    }
  }
];
```

**Why This Matters:**
- **Problem:** Direct Postgres output can be `undefined` or have inconsistent structure
- **Solution:** Always returns object with `messages` array (even if empty: `[]`)
- **Benefit:** Frontend can safely do `result.messages.forEach()` without null checks

**Empty Session Example:**
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "messages": [],
  "count": 0,
  "session_id": "new_session_123"
}
```

**Existing Session Example:**
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "user",
      "content": "Hello!",
      "created_at": "2025-10-23T10:30:00Z"
    },
    {
      "role": "assistant",
      "content": "Hi! How can I help?",
      "created_at": "2025-10-23T10:30:05Z"
    }
  ],
  "count": 2,
  "session_id": "session_vqf27hq8x"
}
```

---

### Phase 4: HTTP Response
**Node:** "Respond: Return History"
**Type:** Respond to Webhook
**Response Mode:** JSON

**Response Body:**
```javascript
={{ $json }}
```
(Passes through the normalized object from Code node)

**CORS Headers:**
```
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: POST, GET, OPTIONS
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type
```

**Why CORS Matters:**
- Allows frontend to call from GitHub Pages (different domain)
- Enables localhost development
- Supports future deployment scenarios

---

## 5. Frontend Integration

### Chat Module v1.5.0 Implementation

**Endpoint Configuration:**
```javascript
this.endpoints = {
    // ... other endpoints
    loadHistory: 'https://n8n.srv997771.hstgr.cloud/webhook/load-conversation-history'
};
```

**Backend Loading Function:**
```javascript
async loadConversationHistoryFromBackend(sessionId) {
    const maxContext = parseInt(localStorage.getItem('cfg_max_context') || '100');

    const response = await this.fetchWithTimeout(this.endpoints.loadHistory, {
        method: 'POST',
        headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
        body: JSON.stringify({
            chat_session_id: sessionId,
            max_context: maxContext
        })
    });

    const result = await response.json();

    if (result.success && result.messages) {
        // Display messages in UI
        result.messages.forEach(msg => {
            this.addMessageToUI(msg.role === 'user' ? 'user' : 'ai', msg.content);
        });

        console.log(` Loaded ${result.count} messages from database`);
        return true;
    }

    return false;
}
```

**When Called:**
- On project switch (`switchToChat()`)
- Before falling back to localStorage
- Provides true platform-agnostic persistence

---

## 6. Database Schema Reference

### conversation_history Table
```sql
CREATE TABLE conversation_history (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    session_id VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    role VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,  -- 'user' or 'assistant'
    content TEXT NOT NULL,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    INDEX idx_session_created (session_id, created_at)
);
```

**Index Strategy:**
- Composite index on `(session_id, created_at)` optimizes our query
- Supports fast lookups and chronological ordering
- Shared with Master Workflow (same table)

---

## 7. Comparison with Master Workflow History

### Master Workflow: "Get Recent history"
- **Purpose:** Immediate context for AI responses
- **Limit:** Fixed 6 messages
- **Order:** DESC (newest first, then reversed)
- **Use Case:** Building prompt context
- **Scope:** Last few conversational turns

### Load Conversation History: This Workflow
- **Purpose:** Full conversation display and persistence
- **Limit:** Configurable (20-100+)
- **Order:** ASC (oldest first for UI display)
- **Use Case:** Cross-device chat restoration
- **Scope:** Complete conversation history

**They complement each other:**
- Master Workflow: Real-time chat operation
- This Workflow: Historical retrieval and display

---

## 8. Version History

### v1.1.0 (October 23, 2025) - **CURRENT**
**Changes:**
- Added Code normalization node (Phase 3)
- Prevents `messages: undefined` errors
- Always returns array structure
- Better empty session handling

**Fixes:**
-  Consistent response format
-  Frontend JSON parsing reliability
-  Graceful empty result handling

### v1.0.0 (October 22, 2025) - **ARCHIVE**
**Initial Implementation:**
- 3-node workflow (Webhook  Postgres  Respond)
- Basic conversation loading
- Direct Postgres output (caused undefined issues)

**Why Upgraded:**
- Empty sessions returned malformed responses
- Frontend couldn't rely on message array existence
- v1.1.0 fixes these issues with normalization layer

---

## 9. Testing & Validation

### PowerShell Test Script
```powershell
$body = @{
    chat_session_id = "session_vqf27hq8x"
    max_context = 10
} | ConvertTo-Json

Invoke-RestMethod -Uri "https://n8n.srv997771.hstgr.cloud/webhook/load-conversation-history" `
    -Method Post `
    -Body $body `
    -ContentType "application/json"
```

### Expected Results

**Existing Session:**
```
success messages                                          count session_id
------- --------                                          ----- ----------
   True {@{role=user; content=Hello!; created_at=...}}       1 session_vqf27hq8x
```

**Empty/New Session:**
```
success messages count session_id
------- -------- ----- ----------
   True {}           0 new_session_123
```

### Browser Console Test
```javascript
fetch('https://n8n.srv997771.hstgr.cloud/webhook/load-conversation-history', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({
        chat_session_id: 'session_vqf27hq8x',
        max_context: 50
    })
})
.then(r => r.json())
.then(data => console.log(' Loaded:', data.count, 'messages'))
```

---

## 10. Troubleshooting Guide

### Problem: Returns 0 messages for existing session
**Possible Causes:**
- Wrong `chat_session_id` format
- Session exists but with different ID pattern
- Database connection issue

**Debug Steps:**
1. Check n8n execution log for actual query
2. Run SQL directly in database:
   ```sql
   SELECT DISTINCT session_id FROM conversation_history LIMIT 10;
   ```
3. Verify session_id format matches

---

### Problem: "messages: undefined" in frontend
**Cause:** Using v1.0.0 instead of v1.1.0

**Solution:**
- Import Load_Conversation_History_v1.1.0.json
- Ensure Code normalization node is present
- v1.1.0 fixes this issue

---

### Problem: CORS errors from frontend
**Cause:** Missing CORS headers in Response node

**Solution:**
- Verify "Respond: Return History" node has headers:
  - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *`
  - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods: POST, GET, OPTIONS`
  - `Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type`

---

### Problem: Query timeout with large result sets
**Cause:** Requesting too many messages (max_context too high)

**Solution:**
- Limit max_context to reasonable value (100-200)
- Consider pagination for very large conversations
- Add database query timeout monitoring

---

## 11. Security Considerations

### Current Implementation
- **No Authentication:** Endpoint is publicly accessible
- **Risk Level:** LOW (read-only, no sensitive data modification)
- **Mitigation:** session_id is non-guessable UUID format

### Future Enhancements
Consider adding:
- API key authentication
- Rate limiting
- IP whitelisting for production
- User-specific session access control

---

## 12. Performance Optimization

### Current Performance
- **Query Time:** ~50-200ms (typical)
- **Network Time:** ~100-300ms (depends on location)
- **Total Time:** ~200-500ms end-to-end

### Optimization Strategies
1. **Database Index:** Already optimized with `(session_id, created_at)` composite index
2. **LIMIT Clause:** Prevents loading thousands of messages
3. **Minimal Columns:** Only fetches `role`, `content`, `created_at` (not full row)
4. **Frontend Caching:** localStorage acts as cache after first load

### Scalability Notes
- Current design handles 100-1000 sessions easily
- For 10,000+ sessions, consider:
  - Connection pooling
  - Query result caching
  - CDN for static deployment

---

## 13. Integration with Platform Ecosystem

### Related Components

**Master Chat Workflow:**
- Writes to same `conversation_history` table
- Ensures data is available for this workflow to read
- Creates session_id that this workflow queries

**Chat Module v1.5.0:**
- Consumes this workflow's API
- Implements fallback to localStorage
- Displays loaded messages in UI

**Config Module v1.7:**
- Provides `cfg_max_context` setting
- User controls how many messages to load
- Default: 100 messages

**GitHub Pages Deployment:**
- Hosts frontend that calls this workflow
- Enables true cross-device functionality
- CORS headers make this possible

---

## 14. Success Metrics

### What Success Looks Like
 User opens chat on Computer A
 Conversation saves to database
 User switches to Computer B
 Opens same chat session
 **All messages appear** (loaded from database)
 Can continue conversation seamlessly

### Platform-Agnostic Achievement
- **Before:** Conversations trapped in browser localStorage
- **After:** Conversations accessible from any device
- **Benefit:** True cloud-based chat persistence

---

## 15. API Reference

### Endpoint
```
POST https://n8n.srv997771.hstgr.cloud/webhook/load-conversation-history
```

### Request Headers
```
Content-Type: application/json
```

### Request Body
```json
{
  "chat_session_id": "string (required)",
  "max_context": "number (optional, default: 100)"
}
```

### Response Format
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "session_id": "string",
  "count": "number",
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "user|assistant",
      "content": "string",
      "created_at": "ISO 8601 timestamp"
    }
  ]
}
```

### HTTP Status Codes
- `200 OK`: Success (even if 0 messages)
- `400 Bad Request`: Missing required parameters
- `500 Internal Server Error`: Database/workflow error

---

## 16. Deployment Checklist

Before deploying to production canvas:

- [ ] Import Load_Conversation_History_v1.1.0.json to n8n
- [ ] Verify Postgres credentials are set
- [ ] Test with PowerShell (existing session)
- [ ] Test with PowerShell (empty session)
- [ ] Activate workflow in n8n
- [ ] Copy webhook URL for frontend
- [ ] Update frontend endpoint configuration
- [ ] Test from localhost browser
- [ ] Deploy to GitHub Pages
- [ ] Test from second computer
- [ ] Verify cross-device persistence works
- [ ] Attach this documentation to canvas workflow
- [ ] Download complete canvas for version control

---

**Workflow Version:** v1.1.0
**Status:** Production Ready

parameters.query:
UPDATE project_contexts 
SET project_name = $1, description = $2 
WHERE chat_session_id = $3
RETURNING project_name, description, chat_session_id;

parameters.content:
## Update Project Info Workflow


**Purpose:** Updates project name and description in project_contexts table

**Endpoint:** POST /webhook/update-project-info

**Input:**
```json
{
  "chat_session_id": "session_xyz",
  "project_name": "New Name",
  "description": "New Description"
}
```

**Output:**
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "project_name": "New Name",
  "description": "New Description",
  "chat_session_id": "session_xyz"
}
```

**Notes:**
- Uses chat_session_id as immutable lookup key
- Only updates project_name and description fields
- Returns error if project not found
- CORS enabled for GitHub Pages access

history.content: Project "9/6/25 Test 1" created successfully. Persona: Developer Assistant (A).

Hello my name is mike. I'm doing some testing this morning. I'll be making some statements and then adding them to a memory function I have designed. I'll close this session, restart it and see if you can remember these statements. Are you ready?

Hello Mike! Yes, I'm ready to help with your testing.
Just to set clear expectations: I don't have the ability to retain information between separate chat sessions on my own. Each time you start a new conversation with me, I begin with a fresh slate and no memory of previous interactions.
However, I understand you're testing a memory function you've designed, which sounds like it might work by:

Storing information from our current session
Making that information available to me in future sessions (perhaps through the knowledge base context)

I'm ready to participate in your test! Feel free to share the statements you'd like to test with your memory system.
model?
Here we go...my truck is blue

Got it, Mike! I've noted that your truck is blue.
I'm ready for any additional statements you'd like to share for your memory function testing. Just let me know when you have more information to add or when you're ready to move to the next phase of your test.
model?
the truck is a Ford F350

Perfect! I've now noted:

Your truck is blue
Your truck is a Ford F350

So you have a blue Ford F350. Got it recorded for your memory function test!
Ready for any additional statements or whenever you're ready to proceed to the next phase of testing.
model?
I have a green fan on my desk

Noted, Mike! I now have these details recorded for your memory function test:

Your truck is blue
Your truck is a Ford F350 
You have a green fan on your desk

Three pieces of information logged! Ready for more statements or whenever you want to move to the next phase of your memory system testing.
model?
ok, thanks. I'm going to commit this session to memory (a RAG Vector database), stop/restart and check if you can remember.

Sounds good, Mike! I understand you're testing your memory system by:

Committing this session to your RAG Vector database
Stopping/restarting the system
Testing recall to see if I can remember the details we discussed

The information we covered for your test:

Your truck is blue
Your truck is a Ford F350
You have a green fan on your desk

Go ahead and run your commit process. I'll be ready to demonstrate whether the memory system successfully retrieves this information when you restart and test recall!
model?

Formatting rules: Use Markdown. Prefer short sections with headings when helpful. Use bullet lists for lists. Bold short labels. Use tables only when clearly beneficial. Keep responses concise and scannable.
